Saint Albans is the largest city located in Vermont’s northwestern Franklin County; approximately 16 miles south of the Canadian border. It is comprised both of Saint Albans City and Saint Albans Town with a combined population of about 14,050 residents. It is known as the Maple Sugar Capital of the World and is the home to the annual

Saint Albans can be accessed via exits 19 and 20 off of Interstate 89, as well as some smaller roads such as routes 7, 36, and 104.
As Saint Albans is located on Lake Champlain; it can be accessed by boat from New York, Quebec, Canada, and other parts of western Vermont.
As mentioned above, Saint Albans hosts the Maple Festival every year in late April. Here you can get everything from maple cotton candy to maple ice cream! (http://www.vtmaplefestival.org/).

value: Hard’ak is a local is a ski/sledding hill used by many locals for wintertime fun. (http://www.hardack.org/)

In the heart of downtown is the Weldon Theater, as well as one of the few Drive-In theaters left in the state located directly off exit 20 on I89. (http://www.weldentheatre.com/Welden_Theatre/Home.html)
Mid May – October there is the Northwest Farmers Market located in Taylor Park that takes place on Saturdays from 9:00 – 2:00. (http://www.nwvtfarmersmarket.org/)

Camping (Memorial Day weekend - Labor Day weekend):

value: Burton Island State Park: 240 acres of island with walking trails, campsites, and access via a passenger ferry (http://www.vtstateparks.com/htm/burton.htm)
Camp Kill Kare: Popular recreational day use with lake swimming access (http://www.vtstateparks.com/htm/killkare.htm)
Woods Islandn State Park: Primitive camping on an island in Inland Sea (http://www.vtstateparks.com/htm/woodsisland.htm)
